text: Hey, what's up creators? In this video,
we're going to be kicking off our coin
collection system. That being said,
we're going to be setting up the visuals
for our coin. We're going to create a

the coin shape ready for all of the next
few videos where we're going to be
starting to look at the functionality.
It's going to be a very exciting
session. Let's jump straight into Unreal
Engine. Okay, so inside of Unreal
Engine, the very first thing that I want
you to do is go to your content drawer.
Inside of here, I want you to go to your
content folder, and we're going to make
a new folder called first hour of
Unreal. So, just F H O U. And the reason
why we're creating this folder is just
so that all of the assets that we
create, blueprints or 3D models or user
interface, we can put them all directly
in this folder and find them really
easily. So, once you've created that
folder, go ahead and double click on
that to open it up. What we're going to
do now is actually together create our
very first blueprint. We can do this by
right-clicking in the empty space or by
pressing the add button.
And then what we're going to do is go up
to blueprint class and we are going to
create a blueprint class of the type
actor. An actor is just a regular
blueprint with no functionality attached
to it. It's just a blank canvas for us
to work with.
So go ahead and click actor. And this is
going to create it. And we're going to
give this a name BP_Collectible.
BP just being the naming convention for
a blueprint. Then what I want you to do
is just go ahead and double click on
this to open it up.
You're then probably going to be taken
to the class default that looks like
this. Don't worry if you are. Just go
ahead and make sure that you open the
full blueprint editor. We can do this by
clicking this blue piece of text up
here. With that done, you're now going
to be in an interface that is very
similar to what you saw with the player
blueprint. What I mean by that is we now
have our components, we have our
viewport, and we have our event graph.
What we're going to be doing is going
into this viewport here, and we're going
to add a component for this coin. So, in
our components, we're going to go to
add, and we're going to see what we can
find inside of here that might work for
us. So, what I'm going to search for is
a cylinder.
This cylinder is going to be really
simple. It's going to look like this.
And what I'm going to do with this is
I'm actually going to click on it. And
then I'm going to press the R key to go
into scale mode. And I'm just going to
scale this down until it starts to look
like a coin.
I've got all of my same snapping and
control settings in the top leftand
corner here. I'm just going to turn off
my snapping for my scale.
And I'm just going to get this so it
looks like a coin. So all I've done is
just scaled it down on the vertical axis
on the Z. And now what I'm going to do
is press E to go into my rotate mode.
And then I'm just going to rotate it on
its side just like this. And then once
I've done that, I'm going to press
compile and save to save what we've
done. Now, that is the first steps in
setting up our collectible. If we wanted
to, we could now place this in our
scene. So, what I'm going to do is just
place it into my scene just like that by
just dragging and dropping that
blueprint.
Now, that looks okay, but couple of

we're going to do is address the size.
It's way too big. Going to go back into

Compile and save. And then with that

coin and it looks like a good size.
Okay. So that's it. Our coin is now
